msContents.summary: The Avadānaśataka is an ancient collection of Buddhist legends, its first redaction dating to the first centuries of the CE. It was translated into Chinese and Tibetan during the first millennium CE, gaining large popularity across Asia. This Nepalese manuscript, dated 1645 CE, is the one on which J. Speyer based his editio princeps of 1902. Older fragmentary palm leaf manuscripts have survived, but this is the oldest complete source for the reconstruction of the text.

msItem.title: Avadānaśataka
Śatakāvadāna
msItem.incipit: [1r1] pūrṇṇabhadro yaśomatī kuśīdā vaṇijas tathā | somo vaḍiś ca padmāṅkaḥ | pañcālo dhūmra eva ca || rājānaṃ paścimaṃ kṛtvā vargo hy eṣa samudditaḥ | janapadacaryāyāṃ pūrṇṇabhadra iti | buddho bhagavān satkṛto mānitaḥ pūjito rājabhī rājamātrair ddhanibhiḥ pauraiḥ śre[1r2]ṣṭhibhiḥ sārthavāhaiḥ devair nāgair yakṣair asurair garuḍaiḥ | kinnarair mahoragair iti devanāgayakṣāsuragaruḍakinnaramahoragābhyarcito buddho bhagavāṃ jñāto mahāpuṇyo lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātaśayanāsanaglānapratyayabhaiṣajyapariṣkārāṇāṃ saśrāvakasaṃgho maṇḍapeyaṃ pravacanaṃ [1r3] pratinavaś ca buddho tyādoyāvadevamanuṣyebhyaḥ samyak.prakāsito rājaḥgṛham upanisṛtya viharati | veṇuvane kalandakanivāpe |
msItem.finalRubric: [4v7] idam avocad bhagavān āttamanasas te ca bhikṣavo bhagavato bhāṣitam abhyanandan_ || @ 3 || iti kuśīdāvadānaṃ samāptaṃ || @ ||
msItem.rubric:
[11r10] || @ || uddānaṃ nāvā stambhañ ca snātraṃ ca tatheti pratisarakaṃ pāñcavārṣikaṃ stutir varadaḥ kāśikaṃ divyabhojanam || @ ||
Note: the third pāda is hypermetric.
[20v7] || @ || uddānaṃ candano hy atha padmaś ca -1- ca kraṃ daśaśirās tathā | sūkṣmītvac chītadīptaś ca nāvikā gandhamādanaḥ | nirmalo valgu[20v8]ś ca varge bhavati samuddhitaḥ || @||

[28v11] || @ || uddānaṃ padmakaḥ kavaḍaś caiva dharmapālaḥ śibis tathā | surūpo maitrakarṇyaś ca śaśo dharmagaviṣiṇā | anāthapiṇḍadaḥ subhadraś ca vargo bhavati samudditaṃ || @ ||
Note: the last two pādas are hypermetric.
msItem.finalRubric:
[40r8] ||^^^|| avadānaśatake caturthī udānagā[40r9]thā bodhisatvajātakānāṃ samāptaḥ || 39 ||
Note: For the reason of the discrepancy in the numbering of the avadānas, see Speyer 1902.
msItem.rubric:
[40r9] || @ || uddānaṃ guḍaśālā ca bhaktaṃ ca toyaṃ varcaghaṭena ca | koliko hy uttaraś cāpi jātyandhaḥ śreṣṭhir eva ca putro jāmbālakaś caiva vargo bhavati samudditaḥ ||
Note: at the end of the second pāda, a small daṇḍa in red ink has been added above the line.
[48r13] uddānaṃ kṛṣṇasarppaś ca candraś ca sālā śrīmatir eva ca vastraṃ śukaś ca dūtaś ca mahiṣaḥ poṣadhaś caiva māṃso bhavati paścimaḥ ||
[58v4] uddānaṃ suvarṇṇābhaḥ sugandhiś ra vapuṣmān balavā[58v5]n priyaḥ padmākṣo duṃdubhiḥ putrasūryo mallapatākayoḥ || @ ||
[66r8] uddānaṃ suprā supriyā caiva śuklā somāṃ tathā parā juvalayā sundarī caiva | muktī caiva kacaṃgalā kṣemā virūpā ca vargo bhavati samuditaḥ ||
[75v9] uddānaṃ samudraḥ sumanāś caiva hiraṇyapāṇis tripiṭena ca yasomitrau papādau ca śobhitaḥ | bhadriko rāṣṭra[75v10]pālaś ca vargo bhavati samudditaḥ ||^^^||
[86v10] uddānaṃ subhūti sthaviraś cāpi haste lekyuṃcidakena ca sasāro guptikaś cāpi virūpo gaṃgikena ca dīrghanakhaḥ saṃgītiś ca vargo bhavati samudditaḥ || @ ||
msItem.explicit: [98v5] atha rājāśo-1-ka āyuṣmataḥ sthaviropaguptasya bhāṣitam abhyanaṃdyānumodya utthāyāsanāt prakrāntaḥ || 100 ||
msItem.finalRubric: [98v5] ity avadānaśatake daśamī udānagāthā samāptā || @ || [98v6] samāptaṃ ca avadānaśatakaṃ hy atrayaṃ sugatabhāṣitaṃ thaṃdīśvarācāryapūrvam īdānīṃ prakāśitaṃ ||
msItem.colophon: [98v6] ye dharmā hetuprabhavā hetu teṣāṃ tathāgataḥ | hy avadayo nirodha evaṃvādī mahāśramaḥ || ^ || śreyo stu saṃvat 765 phalguṇakṛṣṇacaturthyāṃ -7- saṃpūrṇṇajātā śubha

filiation.p: Antigraph: E 1554-24 (NGMCP), see Demoto 2006: 214-5, After having compared one third of this ms with Speyer's edition we gained the impression that the new manuscript is the direct source of B. (B is Speyer's siglum for Add.1611, see Speyer 1902: CIII: B = Cambr. Add.1611).

Apographs: the Avadānaśataka text rests on one MS, the Cambridge Add.1611 [...] The other three MSS I have collated, CDP have been copied from it (Speyer 1902: CIII-CVII; see also Demoto 2006: 208).
Add.1386 = C in Speyer's edition (Speyer 1902: CV)
Hodgson manuscript in the India Office Library = D in Speyer's edition (Speyer 1902: CV)
Hodgson manuscript D. 122 in the Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris = P in Speyer's edition (Speyer 1902: CVI).
Add.1680.2 is the only source independent from B (Demoto 2006: 208).

supportDesc.foliation: Tiny Nepālākṣarā numerals, bottom right corner, verso.

layoutDesc.layout:
6.8 32
13 lines per page (There are a few pages of 14 lines (f. 31a. f. 33v. f. 58a and b. f. 60b. f. 62b.), still less of 12 (f. 34a f. 94b) [Speyer 1902: CIII]); approximately 96 akṣaras per line.
3
2
Very regular single marginal frame lines; accurate ruling with a module of 5 mm. On the whole, the layout has been very carefully planned (a fact corroborated also by the handwriting, as pointed out by Bendall [1883: XXXIII] and Speyer [1902: CIII]).
The end of each avadāna is marked by highlighting with red powder the last words of the story —always a formulaic passage, idam avocad bhagavān āttamanasas te bhikṣavo bhagavato bhāṣitam abhyanandan—, followed by puṣpikās of different shapes and the number of the story. The title of the following story is then provided in an abbreviated form (for instance, yaśomatīti on f. 2r4). Occasionally, a complete final rubric for an avadāna is provided (for instance the third, the Kuśīdāvadāna). The end of each decade is marked in the same way as the end of the avadānas. Each decade begins with an uddāna, a stanza listing the titles of the avadānas of the new decade.

handNote.desc: First hand: Nepālākṣarā in black ink, main text, some marginal corrections and additions (see below).

Second hand: Nepālākṣarā in black ink, corrections added in the margins by different hands, the number of which is difficult to ascertain (Speyer 1902: CIV, Of the marginal and interlinear corrections, some are doubtless written by the same hand as the manuscript [...] A good deal, of them may, however, rather be ascribed to one (or more) secunda(e) manus as sometimes appears from differences of handwriting).

item.marginalia: Running marginal title ( $ śata), top left margin, verso.
Many corrections and missing passages added in the margins by the first hand (for instance on f. 36v and 38v) and other hands.

history.provenance: Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright in 1873-6.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
